\usepackage{amsmath}

\usepackage{babel}
\begin{document}
\title{Green function}
\date{Jie Ren}
\maketitle

\section{From Lattice System to Field Theory}

We will focus on systems that:
\begin{itemize}
\item live on $L^{d}$-site lattice,
\item with time-independent Hamiltonian,
\item have translational symmetry,
\item are in ground states or thermal equilibrium states.
\end{itemize}
We treat particle operator on lattice as the fundamental theory. And
then taking the thermodynamics limit to define the continuous field
theory. The Green function can be defined both for both lattice and
field, and the two definitions can be related.

\subsection{Discrete lattice}

The elementary particle operators have commutation relation:

\[
\left[c_{i,\alpha},c_{j,\beta}\right]_{\mp}=\left[c_{i,\alpha}^{\dagger},c_{j,\beta}^{\dagger}\right]_{\mp}=0,
\]

\[
\left[c_{i,\alpha},c_{j,\beta}^{\dagger}\right]_{\mp}=\delta_{ij}\delta_{\alpha\beta}
\]
for Bosonic and Fermionic system respectively. In momentum space,
the particle operators are defined as:

\begin{eqnarray*}
c_{\bm{k}_{n},\alpha} & = & \frac{1}{L^{d/2}}\sum_{j}e^{-i\bm{k}_{n}\cdot\bm{x}_{j}}c_{j,\alpha}\\
c_{j,\alpha} & = & \frac{1}{L^{d/2}}\sum_{n}e^{+i\bm{k}_{n}\cdot\bm{x}_{j}}c_{\bm{k}_{n},\alpha}
\end{eqnarray*}
where the discrete lattice coordinates and crystal momentums are:

\begin{eqnarray*}
\bm{x}_{j} & = & a\left(j_{1},\cdots,j_{d}\right),\\
\bm{k}_{n} & = & \frac{2\pi}{aL}\left(n_{1},\cdots,n_{d}\right),
\end{eqnarray*}
where $a$ is the lattice constant. In this way, the commutation relation
on momentum space is still normalized:

\[
\left[c_{\bm{k}_{m},\alpha},c_{\bm{k}_{n},\beta}\right]_{\mp}=\left[c_{\bm{k}_{m},\alpha}^{\dagger},c_{\bm{k}_{n},\beta}^{\dagger}\right]_{\mp}=0,
\]

\[
\left[c_{\bm{k}_{m},\alpha},c_{\bm{k}_{n},\beta}^{\dagger}\right]_{\mp}=\delta_{mn}\delta_{\alpha\beta}.
\]
When consider the time revolution, the operator in the Heisenberg
picture is

\begin{eqnarray*}
c_{i,\alpha}\left(t\right) & = & e^{iHt}c_{i,\alpha}e^{-iHt},\\
c_{\bm{k},\alpha}\left(t\right) & = & e^{iHt}c_{\bm{k},\alpha}e^{-iHt}.
\end{eqnarray*}


\subsection{Continuous field}

We are now to define a continuous theory. The procedure is done by:
\begin{enumerate}
\item Fourier transform the particle operator to momentum space,
\item taking thermodynamics limit to make the crystal momentum continuous,
\item define the total particle number to fix normalization.
\end{enumerate}
Knowing the momentum space particle operator, we then take the $L\rightarrow\infty$
limit, the frequency summation under this limit becomes:

\[
\lim_{L\rightarrow\infty}\sum_{\bm{k}_{m}}=\left(aL\right)^{d}\int\frac{d^{d}k}{\left(2\pi\right)^{d}}=\mathcal{V}\int\frac{d^{d}k}{\left(2\pi\right)^{d}}.
\]
We would like to substitute the lattice particle operators with a
continuous field operator:

\[
c_{\bm{k}_{n},\alpha}\rightarrow\psi_{\bm{k},\alpha}
\]
We let the total particle number to be

\[
N_{\alpha}=\int\frac{d^{d}k}{\left(2\pi\right)^{d}}\psi_{\bm{k},\alpha}^{\dagger}\psi_{\bm{k},\alpha}
\]
so that we can use

\[
\int\frac{d^{d}k}{\left(2\pi\right)^{d}}\psi_{\bm{k},\alpha}^{\dagger}\psi_{\bm{k},\alpha}=\sum_{n}c_{\bm{k}_{n},\alpha}^{\dagger}c_{\bm{k}_{n},\alpha}
\]
to determine the normalization:
\[
\psi_{\bm{k},\alpha}=\sqrt{\mathcal{V}}c_{\bm{k}_{n},\alpha}
\]
Under such definition, the commutation relation becomes

\[
\left[\psi_{\bm{k},\alpha},\psi_{\bm{k}',\beta}^{\dagger}\right]_{\mp}=\delta_{\alpha\beta}\delta_{\bm{k}\bm{k}'}\mathcal{V}=\delta_{\alpha\beta}\left(2\pi\right)^{d}\delta\left(\bm{k}-\bm{k}'\right).
\]
The right-hand-side can be replaced by a delta function since

\[
\int d^{d}x=\left(2\pi\right)^{d}\delta\left(0\right)=\lim_{L\rightarrow\infty}\mathcal{V}.
\]
The field operator is defined as
\[
\psi_{\alpha}\left(\bm{x}\right)=\int\frac{d^{d}k}{\left(2\pi\right)^{d}}e^{+i\bm{k}\cdot\bm{x}}\psi_{\bm{k},\alpha}.
\]
The commutation relation for the field is

\[
\left[\psi_{\alpha}\left(\bm{x}\right),\psi_{\beta}^{\dagger}\left(\bm{x}'\right)\right]_{\mp}=\delta_{\alpha\beta}\delta^{d}\left(\bm{x}-\bm{x}'\right).
\]
The relation to lattice theory is also given by fixing particle number:

\[
N_{\alpha}=\int d^{d}x\psi_{\alpha}^{\dagger}\left(\bm{x}\right)\psi_{\alpha}\left(\bm{x}\right).
\]
Using

\[
\int d^{d}x=a^{d}\sum_{j},
\]
we have

\[
c_{j}=a^{d/2}\psi_{\alpha}\left(\bm{x}_{j}\right).
\]
When including time revolution:

\[
\psi_{\alpha}\left(\bm{x},t\right)=e^{iHt}\psi\left(\bm{x}\right)e^{-iHt}.
\]
In summary, the lattice and field theory is related to each other
by the substitution:

\begin{eqnarray*}
\sum_{\bm{k}_{n}} & \leftrightarrow & \mathcal{V}\int\frac{d^{d}k}{\left(2\pi\right)^{d}}\\
\sum_{i} & \leftrightarrow & \int\frac{d^{d}x}{a^{d}}\\
c_{\bm{k},\alpha} & \leftrightarrow & \frac{1}{\sqrt{\mathcal{V}}}\psi_{\bm{k},\alpha}\\
c_{j,\alpha} & \leftrightarrow & a^{d/2}\psi_{\alpha}\left(\bm{x}_{j}\right)\\
\delta_{\bm{k}\bm{k}'}\mathcal{V} & \leftrightarrow & \left(2\pi\right)^{d}\delta\left(\bm{k}-\bm{k}\right)
\end{eqnarray*}


\subsection{Green function and Lehmann representation}

The Green functions is defined by the field operator:

\begin{eqnarray*}
G_{\alpha\beta}^{T}\left(\bm{x},t;\bm{x}',t'\right) & = & -i\left\langle T_{t}\left[\psi_{\alpha}\left(\bm{x},t\right)\psi_{\beta}^{\dagger}\left(\bm{x}',t\right)\right]\right\rangle \\
G_{\alpha\beta}^{R}\left(\bm{x},t;\bm{x}',t'\right) & = & -i\theta\left(t-t'\right)\left\langle \left[\psi_{\alpha}\left(\bm{x},t\right),\psi_{\beta}^{\dagger}\left(\bm{x}',t\right)\right]_{\mp}\right\rangle \\
G_{\alpha\beta}^{A}\left(\bm{x},t;\bm{x}',t'\right) & = & i\theta\left(t'-t\right)\left\langle \left[\psi_{\alpha}\left(\bm{x},t\right),\psi_{\beta}^{\dagger}\left(\bm{x}',t\right)\right]_{\mp}\right\rangle \\
\mathcal{G}_{\alpha\beta}\left(\bm{x},\tau;\bm{x}',\tau'\right) & = & -i\left\langle T_{\tau}\left[\psi_{\alpha}\left(\bm{x},\tau\right)\psi_{\beta}^{\dagger}\left(\bm{x}',\tau\right)\right]\right\rangle 
\end{eqnarray*}
The bracket can be interpreted as ground state expectation or thermal
average. In momentum space:

\begin{eqnarray*}
G_{\alpha\beta}\left(\bm{k},t\right) & = & \int d^{d}x\ e^{-i\bm{k}\cdot\left(\bm{x}-\bm{x}'\right)}G_{\alpha\beta}\left(x-x',t\right).
\end{eqnarray*}
It can be shown that Green function in momentum space can be directly
calculated using lattice particle operator:

\begin{eqnarray*}
G_{\alpha\beta}^{T}\left(\bm{k},t-t'\right) & = & -i\left\langle T_{t}\left[c_{\bm{k},\alpha}\left(t\right)c_{\bm{k},\beta}^{\dagger}\left(t'\right)\right]\right\rangle \\
G_{\alpha\beta}^{R}\left(\bm{k},t-t'\right) & = & -i\theta\left(t-t'\right)\left\langle \left[c_{\bm{k},\alpha}\left(t\right),c_{\bm{k},\beta}^{\dagger}\left(t'\right)\right]_{\mp}\right\rangle \\
G_{\alpha\beta}^{A}\left(\bm{k},t-t'\right) & = & i\theta\left(t'-t\right)\left\langle \left[c_{\bm{k},\alpha}\left(t\right),c_{\bm{k},\beta}^{\dagger}\left(t'\right)\right]_{\mp}\right\rangle \\
\mathcal{G}_{\alpha\beta}\left(\bm{k},t-t'\right) & = & -i\left\langle T_{\tau}\left[c_{\bm{k},\alpha}\left(t\right)c_{\bm{k},\beta}^{\dagger}\left(t'\right)\right]\right\rangle 
\end{eqnarray*}
In frequency space:

\[
G_{\alpha\beta}\left(\bm{k},\omega\right)=\int d^{d}t\ e^{i\omega t}G_{\alpha\beta}\left(\bm{k},t\right).
\]
It helpful to define two more functions, as they are the building
block of other Green functions:

\begin{eqnarray*}
G_{\alpha\beta}^{>}\left(\bm{x},t;\bm{x}',t'\right) & = & -i\left\langle \psi_{\alpha}\left(\bm{x},t\right)\psi_{\beta}^{\dagger}\left(\bm{x}',t\right)\right\rangle \\
G_{\alpha\beta}^{<}\left(\bm{x},t;\bm{x}',t'\right) & = & \mp i\left\langle \psi_{\beta}^{\dagger}\left(\bm{x}',t\right)\psi_{\alpha}\left(\bm{x},t\right)\right\rangle \\
G_{\alpha\beta}^{>}\left(\bm{k},t\right) & = & -i\left\langle c_{\bm{k},\alpha}\left(t\right)c_{\bm{k},\beta}^{\dagger}\right\rangle \\
G_{\alpha\beta}^{<}\left(\bm{k},t\right) & = & \mp i\left\langle c_{\bm{k},\beta}^{\dagger}c_{\bm{k},\alpha}\left(t\right)\right\rangle 
\end{eqnarray*}
Now insert identity resolution into the average

\begin{eqnarray*}
G_{\alpha\beta}^{>}\left(\bm{k},t\right) & = & -\frac{i}{Z}\sum_{nm}\rho_{n}\left\langle n\right|c_{\bm{k},\alpha}\left(t\right)\left|m\right\rangle \left\langle m\right|c_{\bm{k},\beta}^{\dagger}\left|n\right\rangle \\
 & = & -\frac{i}{Z}\sum_{nm}\rho_{n}e^{-i\left(\epsilon_{n}-\epsilon_{m}\right)t}\left\langle n\right|c_{\bm{k},\alpha}\left|m\right\rangle \left\langle m\right|c_{\bm{k},\beta}^{\dagger}\left|n\right\rangle 
\end{eqnarray*}

\begin{eqnarray*}
G_{\alpha\beta}^{<}\left(\bm{k},t\right) & = & \mp\frac{i}{Z}\sum_{nm}\rho_{m}\left\langle m\right|c_{\bm{k},\beta}^{\dagger}\left|n\right\rangle \left\langle n\right|c_{\bm{k},\alpha}\left(t\right)\left|m\right\rangle \\
 & = & \mp\frac{i}{Z}\sum_{nm}\rho_{m}e^{-i\left(\epsilon_{n}-\epsilon_{m}\right)t}\left\langle n\right|c_{\bm{k},\alpha}\left|m\right\rangle \left\langle m\right|c_{\bm{k},\beta}^{\dagger}\left|n\right\rangle 
\end{eqnarray*}
So the time ordered Green function is

\begin{eqnarray*}
G_{\alpha\beta}^{T}\left(\bm{k},t\right) & = & \theta\left(t\right)G_{\alpha\beta}^{>}\left(\bm{k},t\right)+\theta\left(-t\right)G_{\alpha\beta}^{<}\left(\bm{k},t\right)\\
G_{\alpha\beta}^{T}\left(\bm{k},\omega\right) & = & \int\frac{d\omega'}{2\pi}\left[\frac{A\left(\bm{k},\omega'\right)}{\omega-\omega'+i\eta}\mp\frac{B\left(\bm{k},\omega'\right)}{\omega-\omega'-i\eta}\right],
\end{eqnarray*}
where the spectrum function is:

\begin{eqnarray*}
A\left(\bm{k},\omega'\right) & = & \frac{1}{Z}\sum_{nm}\rho_{n}\left\langle n\right|c_{\bm{k},\alpha}\left|m\right\rangle \left\langle m\right|c_{\bm{k},\beta}^{\dagger}\left|n\right\rangle \delta\left(\omega'-\epsilon_{n}+\epsilon_{m}\right)\\
B\left(\bm{k},\omega'\right) & = & \frac{1}{Z}\sum_{nm}\rho_{m}\left\langle n\right|c_{\bm{k},\alpha}\left|m\right\rangle \left\langle m\right|c_{\bm{k},\beta}^{\dagger}\left|n\right\rangle \delta\left(\omega'-\epsilon_{n}+\epsilon_{m}\right)
\end{eqnarray*}
The retarded function is

\begin{eqnarray*}
G_{\alpha\beta}^{R}\left(\bm{k},t\right) & = & \theta\left(t\right)\left[G_{\alpha\beta}^{>}\left(\bm{k},t\right)-G_{\alpha\beta}^{<}\left(\bm{k},t\right)\right]\\
G_{\alpha\beta}^{R}\left(\bm{k},\omega\right) & = & \int\frac{d\omega'}{2\pi}\frac{A\left(\bm{k},\omega'\right)\mp B\left(\bm{k},\omega'\right)}{\omega-\omega'+i\eta},
\end{eqnarray*}
Similarly, the advanced function is

\begin{eqnarray*}
G_{\alpha\beta}^{A}\left(\bm{k},t\right) & = & -\theta\left(-t\right)\left[G_{\alpha\beta}^{>}\left(\bm{k},t\right)-G_{\alpha\beta}^{<}\left(\bm{k},t\right)\right]\\
G_{\alpha\beta}^{A}\left(\bm{k},\omega\right) & = & \int\frac{d\omega'}{2\pi}\frac{A\left(\bm{k},\omega'\right)\mp B\left(\bm{k},\omega'\right)}{\omega-\omega'-i\eta},
\end{eqnarray*}
Using identity:

\[
\frac{1}{\omega\pm i\eta}=\mathcal{P}\frac{1}{\omega}\mp i\pi\delta\left(\omega\right),
\]
and we have the general structure for real-time Green function:

\[
ReG_{\alpha\beta}^{T}\left(\bm{k},\omega\right)=ReG_{\alpha\beta}^{R}\left(\bm{k},\omega\right)=ReG_{\alpha\beta}^{A}\left(\bm{k},\omega\right),
\]

\[
ImG_{\alpha\beta}^{R}\left(\bm{k},\omega\right)=-ImG_{\alpha\beta}^{A}\left(\bm{k},\omega\right).
\]
For Matsubara function:

\begin{eqnarray*}
\mathcal{G}_{\alpha\beta}\left(\bm{k},\tau\right) & = & -iG_{\alpha\beta}^{>}\left(\bm{k},\tau=it\right)\\
 & = & -\frac{1}{Z}\sum_{nm}\rho_{n}e^{-\left(\epsilon_{n}-\epsilon_{m}\right)\tau}\left\langle n\right|c_{\bm{k},\alpha}\left|m\right\rangle \left\langle m\right|c_{\bm{k},\beta}^{\dagger}\left|n\right\rangle 
\end{eqnarray*}

\[
\int_{0}^{\beta}d\tau e^{\left(i\omega_{n}-\epsilon_{n}+\epsilon_{m}\right)\tau}=\frac{\pm e^{-\beta\left(\epsilon_{n}-\epsilon_{m}\right)}-1}{i\omega_{n}-\epsilon_{n}+\epsilon_{m}}
\]

\[
\mathcal{G}_{\alpha\beta}\left(\bm{k},i\omega_{n}\right)=\int\frac{d\omega'}{2\pi}\frac{A\left(\bm{k},\omega'\right)}{i\omega_{n}-\omega'},
\]
where the spectrum function is

\[
A\left(\bm{k},\omega'\right)=\frac{1}{Z}\sum_{nm}\rho_{n}\left(1\mp e^{-\beta\left(\epsilon_{n}-\epsilon_{m}\right)}\right)\left\langle n\right|c_{\bm{k},\alpha}\left|m\right\rangle \left\langle m\right|c_{\bm{k},\beta}^{\dagger}\left|n\right\rangle \delta\left(\omega'-\epsilon_{n}+\epsilon_{m}\right).
\]


\section{Non-interacting System}

Suppose after diagonalization, the lattice Hamiltonian becomes

\[
\hat{H}=\sum_{\sigma}\sum_{\bm{k}}\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)c_{\bm{k},\sigma}^{\dagger}c_{\bm{k},\sigma}.
\]
Then we can define:

\begin{eqnarray*}
c_{k,\sigma} & = & e^{-i\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)}c_{\bm{k},\sigma}\\
c_{k,\sigma}^{\dagger} & = & e^{+i\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)}c_{\bm{k},\sigma}^{\dagger}\\
\psi_{\sigma}\left(x\right) & = & \int\frac{d^{d}k}{\left(2\pi\right)^{d}}e^{+ik\cdot x}c_{\bm{k},\sigma}\\
\psi_{\sigma}^{\dagger}\left(x\right) & = & \int\frac{d^{d}k}{\left(2\pi\right)^{d}}e^{-ik\cdot x}c_{\bm{k},\sigma}^{\dagger}
\end{eqnarray*}
where

\[
k\cdot x=\bm{k}\cdot\bm{x}-\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)t.
\]


\subsection{Basic correlation function}

The building block of other Green function is:

\begin{eqnarray*}
iG_{\sigma}^{>}\left(\bm{k},t\right) & = & e^{-i\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)t}\left\langle c_{\bm{k},\sigma}c_{\bm{k},\sigma}^{\dagger}\right\rangle \\
 & = & e^{-i\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)t}\left(1\pm n_{\bm{k}}\right),
\end{eqnarray*}

\begin{eqnarray*}
iG_{\sigma}^{>}\left(\bm{k},t\right) & = & \pm e^{-i\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)t}\left\langle c_{\bm{k},\sigma}^{\dagger}c_{\bm{k},\sigma}\right\rangle \\
 & = & \pm e^{-i\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)t}n_{\bm{k}},
\end{eqnarray*}
where

\[
n_{\bm{k}}=\frac{1}{e^{\beta\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)}\mp1}.
\]
For field theory, it can be shown that:

\begin{eqnarray*}
\left\langle \psi_{\bm{k},\sigma}^{\dagger}\psi_{\bm{k}',\sigma'}\right\rangle  & = & \delta_{\sigma\sigma'}\left(2\pi\right)^{d}\delta^{d}\left(\bm{k}-\bm{k}'\right)n_{\bm{k}},\\
\left\langle \psi_{\bm{k},\sigma}\psi_{\bm{k}',\sigma'}^{\dagger}\right\rangle  & = & \delta_{\sigma\sigma'}\left(2\pi\right)^{d}\delta^{d}\left(\bm{k}-\bm{k}'\right)\left(1\pm n_{\bm{k}}\right),
\end{eqnarray*}
two basic green function in field theory are defined as:

\begin{eqnarray*}
iG_{\sigma}^{>}\left(x-x'\right) & = & \left\langle \psi_{\sigma}\left(x\right)\psi_{\sigma}^{\dagger}\left(x'\right)\right\rangle \\
 & = & \int\frac{d^{d}k}{\left(2\pi\right)^{d}}\int\frac{d^{d}k'}{\left(2\pi\right)^{d}}e^{i\left(k\cdot x-k'\cdot x'\right)}\left\langle \psi_{\bm{k},\sigma}\psi_{\bm{k}',\sigma}^{\dagger}\right\rangle \\
 & = & \int\frac{d^{d}k}{\left(2\pi\right)^{d}}e^{ik\cdot\left(x-x'\right)}\left(1\pm n_{\bm{k}}\right)
\end{eqnarray*}

\begin{eqnarray*}
iG_{\sigma}^{<}\left(x-x'\right) & = & \pm\left\langle \psi_{\sigma}^{\dagger}\left(x'\right)\psi_{\sigma}\left(x\right)\right\rangle \\
 & = & \pm\int\frac{d^{d}k}{\left(2\pi\right)^{d}}\int\frac{d^{d}k'}{\left(2\pi\right)^{d}}e^{i\left(k\cdot x-k'\cdot x'\right)}\left\langle \psi_{\bm{k}',\sigma}^{\dagger}\psi_{\bm{k},\sigma}\right\rangle \\
 & = & \pm\int\frac{d^{d}k}{\left(2\pi\right)^{d}}e^{ik\cdot\left(x-x'\right)}n_{\bm{k}}
\end{eqnarray*}
In momentum space:

\begin{eqnarray*}
iG_{\sigma}^{>}\left(\bm{k},t\right) & = & e^{-i\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)t}\left(1\pm n_{\bm{k}}\right),\\
iG_{\sigma}^{<}\left(\bm{k},t\right) & = & \pm e^{-i\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)t}n_{\bm{k}}.
\end{eqnarray*}
This agrees with the result in lattice theory.

\subsection{Time-ordered function}

The time-ordered Green function is

\begin{eqnarray*}
G_{\sigma}^{T}\left(\bm{k},t\right) & = & \theta\left(t\right)G_{\sigma}^{>}\left(\bm{k},t\right)+\theta\left(-t\right)G_{\sigma}^{<}\left(\bm{k},t\right)\\
 & = & -ie^{-i\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)t}\left[\theta\left(t\right)\left(1\pm n_{\bm{k}}\right)\pm\theta\left(-t\right)n_{\bm{k}}\right]\\
 & = & -ie^{-i\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)t}\left[\theta\left(t\right)\pm n_{\bm{k}}\right]
\end{eqnarray*}
Use the identity

\begin{eqnarray*}
\theta\left(+t\right) & = & -\int\frac{d\omega}{2\pi i}\frac{e^{-i\omega t}}{\omega+i\eta},\\
\theta\left(-t\right) & = & +\int\frac{d\omega}{2\pi i}\frac{e^{-i\omega t}}{\omega-i\eta},
\end{eqnarray*}
where $\eta=0^{+}$. The time integral is done by:

\begin{eqnarray*}
-ie^{-i\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)t}\theta\left(t\right) & = & \int\frac{d\omega}{2\pi}\frac{e^{-i\left(\omega+\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)\right)t}}{\omega+i\eta}\\
 & = & \int\frac{d\omega}{2\pi}\frac{e^{-i\omega t}}{\omega-\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)+i\eta}
\end{eqnarray*}

\begin{eqnarray*}
ie^{-i\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)t}\theta\left(-t\right) & = & \pm\int\frac{d\omega}{2\pi}\frac{e^{-i\left(\omega+\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)\right)t}}{\omega-i\eta}\\
 & = & \pm\int\frac{d\omega}{2\pi}\frac{e^{-i\omega t}}{\omega-\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)-i\eta}
\end{eqnarray*}
So the Green function in frequency space is

\[
G_{\sigma}^{T}\left(\bm{k},\omega\right)=\frac{1\pm n_{\bm{k}}}{\omega-\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)+i\eta}\mp\frac{n_{\bm{k}}}{\omega-\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)-i\eta}.
\]
Using identity:

\[
\frac{1}{\omega\pm i\eta}=\mathcal{P}\frac{1}{\omega}\mp i\pi\delta\left(\omega\right).
\]
\begin{eqnarray*}
ReG_{\sigma}^{T}\left(\bm{k},\omega\right) & = & \mathcal{P}\frac{1}{\omega-\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)}\\
ImG_{\sigma}^{T}\left(\bm{k},\omega\right) & = & -\pi\left(1\pm2n_{\bm{k}}\right)\delta\left(\omega-\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(k\right)\right).
\end{eqnarray*}


\subsection{Retarded and advanced function}

The retarded function is:

\begin{eqnarray*}
G_{\sigma}^{R}\left(\bm{k},t\right) & = & -i\theta\left(t\right)\left[G_{\sigma}^{>}\left(\bm{k},t\right)-G_{\sigma}^{<}\left(\bm{k},t\right)\right]\\
 & = & -ie^{-i\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)t}\theta\left(t\right).
\end{eqnarray*}
In frequency space:

\[
G_{\sigma}^{R}\left(\bm{k},\omega\right)=\frac{1}{\omega-\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)+i\eta}.
\]
The advanced function is:

\begin{eqnarray*}
G_{\sigma}^{A}\left(\bm{k},t\right) & = & i\theta\left(-t\right)\left[G_{\sigma}^{>}\left(\bm{k},t\right)-G_{\sigma}^{<}\left(\bm{k},t\right)\right]\\
 & = & ie^{-i\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)t}\theta\left(-t\right).
\end{eqnarray*}
In frequency space:

\[
G_{\sigma}^{A}\left(\bm{k},\omega\right)=\frac{1}{\omega-\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)-i\eta}.
\]
We see that

\[
ReG_{\sigma}^{R}\left(\bm{k},\omega\right)=ReG_{\sigma}^{A}\left(\bm{k},\omega\right)=\frac{1}{\omega-\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)}.
\]

\[
ImG_{\sigma}^{R}\left(\bm{k},\omega\right)=-ImG_{\sigma}^{A}\left(\bm{k},\omega\right)=-\pi\delta\left(\omega-\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)\right).
\]


\subsection{Matsubara function}

For non-interacting system, the Matsubara function and the time-ordered
function is basically identical, by replacing

\begin{eqnarray*}
it & \leftrightarrow & \tau\\
\omega & \leftrightarrow & i\omega_{n}
\end{eqnarray*}

\[
\mathcal{G}_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k},\tau\right)=-e^{-\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)\tau}\left[\theta\left(\tau\right)\pm n_{\bm{k}}\right]
\]
In frequency space:

\begin{eqnarray*}
\mathcal{G}_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k},i\omega_{n}\right) & = & -\int_{0}^{\beta}e^{\left(i\omega_{n}-\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)\right)\tau}\left[1\pm n_{\bm{k}}\right]\\
 & = & \frac{1\mp e^{-\beta\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)}}{i\omega_{n}-\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)}\left[1\pm\frac{1}{e^{\beta\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)}\mp1}\right]\\
 & = & \frac{1}{i\omega_{n}-\epsilon_{\sigma}\left(\bm{k}\right)}.
\end{eqnarray*}

\end{document}
